The Pastor's Normal Class
By the pastor's normal class we suppose is 
meant - a company of christian workers on 
gauised under the special drift of the 
pastor, quitting themselves with particular 
reference to Sunday School work. Its membership 
should at least include the teachers and 
officers of the school - and may include any 
who are willing to subject themselves to the 
discipline of the class and the work for which 
the class is designed to equip. 
The work of such a class is not 
the specific preparation of the lesson for the 
coming sabbath--

But the more general and ground work 
of training and discipline which is essential 
to the work of teaching a particular lesson.  
Just as the Seminary does not undertake
to furnish its students with full fledged Sermons
but only lays the foundation upon which they
can build their own Sermons. The demands
of the present time would seem to require that
the foundation to be laid, or the course over
which this class should take its members should
embrace at least the foll. particulars:
The grounds upon which the divine authority of KJ
Bible rests; an outline of the fundamental doctrines
of the Bible; Rules of interpretation;
the fundamental principles of teaching and the Baptist Articles of Faith. Others may
be included but these should not be left out.
We come then at once to the specification of some
of the more Evident demands for such a class and for
such a course. And first: the teacher demands it.
To but few unclear S.S. Workers dues the unclear Class
seem to be a necessity. 
To the masses, that necessity is yet to be demonstrated.
It is as yet advanced ground. Many regard it
with Suspicion as the product of Some

The main requisite for good S.S. teaching in the

to read a disciplined mind, and the teacher needs
not only intelligence to go with piety, but a

of his class. Perhaps the one thing we need
to preach, and teach, and talk, and every where insist
upon today is - Discipline. This is an Educated
age, or as Dr. J.M. Gregory puts it -
it is a "teaching age". "The world wants facts.
It cares little for what any body thinks. We want
things proven in Science and Theology alike."
If any one needs facts it is the Sunday School
teacher. When men have work to do in any
department of activity, they want a basis
of truth, facts, realities, for their corner stones.
Mighty formative influences are at work on
every hand. Secular Education is not plodding,
it is speeding its way - Religion, which unclear
it its original unclear must not now yield the track
and go plodding on behind. The religious
teacher must have drill akin to not
of the Secular teacher. Every argument for
Normal training in the day School

5
applies with augmented force to the Sunday
School. And for two reasons chiefly 1st -
The relative Superiority of the truth taught in the S.S.
2. only the voluntariness of the S.S. System.
No compelling power is or can be bro't
into the S.S. The whole being 7th Scholar must be drawn
and held by the attractive of the truth itself
and the manner of its presentation. This requires Superior teaching ability.
Then the S.S. teacher is subjected to the
most rigid scrutiny on the part of his schooling
by way of Contrast. The standard and
appliances of the day school are now so
perfect that the S.S. must elevate its
standard if it would maintain its power.
Children measure their teachers by comparison.
Sincerity and Earnestness do not compensate
for well meaning ignorance or other incompeteracy in the mind
of the Child. These little critics Easily detest
the sophisms and superficial Evasions of an
undisciplined teacher. The secret of power lost

6
over many a class is doubtless in the unfavorable
contrast made by the scholar between the
Sunday school teacher and the day school teacher.
Again, if we are not blind to what is
going on around us, we have discovered that
there exists to day a strong tendency to separate
as far as possible at least religious from secular teaching.
The plan is to throw the Bible out of the schools. 
"Limiting morality to those precepts of universal
acceptance, and those ideas of God
and moral responsibility generally received."
But all such moral training is defective
and dangerous, because it lacks the essential
thing upon which all true morality rests vis;
the religion of Jesus Christ. On the other hand
the secular training secured under such
circumstances is also defective. A true Education
needs ever the quickening power of
religious teaching. Now when ever a divorce
actually takes place between these two agencies,
materialism must be the result. How can

7
this be prevented and the right moral training secured?
Not by insisting upon the retention of the Bible in the Schools but
by raising up an 
agency analogous to the public schools,
one equally as potent - "one that will
make the moral and religious instruction
as prominent and specific as the secular
is in our public schools." The Sunday
chool is that agency. Make it as efficient
as it is capable of becoming and we need
nothing better. Trained men and women
must do this work. Again look at the unclear
of the work. If it is Evident that special
training is required for this work, where
shall we look to find the adequate number
to prosecute it? Pastors cannot do it for
the masses must be reached. They may guide
the work but that is all. A host must be
trained to meet a host.
But in advocating this special agency we
are asked the question. Do we not have
Teachers meetings, Institutes,

8
Conventions, and lay Colleges, and what are these for
if they are not for this very purpose? The
question is legitimate and the distinction
should be drawn. The Teachers meeting
has its important mission to fill. 
Its work is Specific & has special reference in the work 
of the coming Sabbath and the routine work of the School
and ought neither to be supplanted by the Normal 
class, nor to undertake the work
of the Normal Class, "The least possible
Teachers meeting we ever knew "Says
Dr. Vincent, failed to become an effective
training school for teachers. Business
to be transacted, specific lessons to the
prepared, and a certain amount of devotional
service to be engaged in, render the pursuit
of a regular course of training impractical."
The Institute approximates more nearly
to what is required, but fails through its
transient character. Held at long 
intervals, and continuing but for a day or
two its efficiency for training is almost
wholly inadequate. Besides the teachers that

9

who usually stay at home. The Institute has
had, and still has its place. It is the
forerunner of a more permanent institution.
It will continue to be in demand at least until
it is supplanted by a normal class
in every Church. The Convention is of a different cast & will
ever be needed as a means for the
mutual encouragement & strength of S.S. workers.
The Seminary or lay College as a popular
means for the training of teachers is too
Expensive and requires too much time
to suit the circumstances of the unclear
of teachers. There is but one conclusion
then to which we can come. If you require
so much at the teachers hands, if you exalt
this work to a profession, you must give
him the facilities for proper preparation, 
and those facilities can no where be supplied
as well as in the Pastor's Normal Class -

child. Who shall have him? is the question.
The Sunday School lifts its plea. 
The child is in danger. The funds you give us
are not equal to those that stand against
us." Infidelity is specious & brazen & seems well posted. It understands 
its own tactics. The child is held by us at a 
disadvantage. We say the Bible is from God, but
we can not prove it. How few of our
teachers understands the grounds on which
the divine authority of the Bible rests and are
able to give them when Gods word is called in
question. This is not all that makes up this
disadvantage. One of the arts of the devil
is to engraft error upon the truth or to
pervert it. The world is full of false doctrine.
Indoctrination, is thus made a prominent
feature of the S.S. teachers work. But
nothing is more neglected. Here seems to be an
aversion to it. And perhaps for two reasons.
1st. "The doctrine do not stand out clear in
the teachers mind. It is hard to teach what
one do not know. 2nd. The religious pendulum

11
has swung up in to the extreme of false liberality
Old time theology is scouted. Creeds are scattered
to the minds - It is popular to decry doctrine.
There is little stability of belief, doubt is running
rampant. The Sunday School Coming
in direct contrast with these things and held responsible for their defeat has a
right to demand that its teachers be thoroughly
equipped in order to successfully meet them.
= But the school demands the existence of a
Normal Class for another reason - That it
may have a high standard of attainment.
It is impossible to lift the child above your
own level. Like teacher, like pupil.
The whole School will take its position according to
the Standard Set before
it. If the standard is below the school,
the school will drop down to it. If it is above
the School, the school will rise up to it.
The Normal Class Exalts the word of God by
making it worthy of the highest attainment. Many 
a child has no doubt come to despise the Bible

12
because it has been apparently treated as
insignificant through the neglect of
careful study on the part of teachers. Gods
word is worthy of the highest place in our minds
& hears and if you would have it occupy
such a position in the minds of the young
you must make it worthy of the best gifts &
highest attainments.
It assures the minds of the most thoughtful
people in the community of the Efficiency of
the School, and so inspires confidence
and enlarges its sphere of influence. You 
must make people believe that your S.S.
work is more than Child's play if your would
enlist their sympathises and Save their Souls.
It is not the poor and the ignorant, and the
half mitted alone that we are trying to save. It
is as well the world of intelligent, thinking
men & women. An intelligent Scholarly - cultured
minister draws a congregation of like characteristics,
and vice versa. And so it is
in Sunday School work. You shall catch the
kind of fish you bait for.

13
Once more, it holds a large reserve force
of teaching talent to be used at a moments
call. One of the most perplexing questions
that has ever agitated the minds of S.S. workers is
how to supply the school with proper teachers,
especially in times of Emergency. In the Normal
Class the question is answered. Every member
holds himself in readiness to fill broken
ranks or to be drafted for permanent
service as the school Enlarges its boundaries.
So classes are saved from seathering, the
interest is kept from declining, and the whole
work of the school is carried steadily on.

14
In the third place the pastor demands it.
The question as to who Shall lead the Normal
Class presents in difficulty to my mind.
I should say with Emphasis the leader properly belongs
to the pastor. It should ever be the pastors
Normal Class. The reasons for this are
obvious. 1st The pastor is supposed to have
had that peculiar training himself which
fits him for the work of training others.
He has passed over nearly the same ground in
College and Seminary which his class will
triverse. No others in his Cong. are suppose to
be so welll adapted then to this work as he.
2nd The pastors work is more
that of Superintending than of doing the
work itself. The Bible holds him responsible as
an "overseer". The work done by the church 
he must account for, if done well it stands
to his credit, if done ill he is responsible
for it. Through the Normal Class he can guide the
whole teaching of the School he can hold in his
hand the reins of all its interests.
But the pastor demands the Normal Class

because it enables him to bring to light the
teaching office which the Bible clearly enjoins
upon every minister of the Gospel. While
Jesus said "Go ye into all the world and
preach the gospel to every creature," He also said
"Go and teach all nations." The minister is
a teacher as well as a preacher. But the teaching
office in its true sense has been to the
ministry a "lost art" for centuries. The 
history of the Catienmentate System reveals the
place and power of this sphere of labor
in the Early Church. If I am not a false
prophet the time is not for distant where our
present preaching system will be modified
so us to include more of the teaching or 
Catechising method. And when that
time comes there will be ten-fold more
honor in the pulpit, and a corresponding
increase of intelligence and efficiency among
the people. (Str. Gibsons Lectures)
The pastor demands it as it enables him to call
out and develop the talent teaching power
of his church. Some philosopher has discovered

16
That there is latent power enough in a single
drop of water if it could be rightly utilised
to shake the world, whether this be true or not. 
There is latent teaching power
in our churches sufficient if it could be
brought out, developed and put to use
to man more than double the work we are
doing to day. And who can do this work
better than the pastor? Whose duty is it if it
is not his? Who needs trained associates
more than he? And how can he better
secure them than through just such an agency
as the Nor. Class? Did not Paul anticipate the need of some such
instrumentality when he said to Timothy, "The things that thou
hast heard of me by many witnesses the same
commit thou to faithful men who shall be able to teach
others also." 
Besides the pastor labors under the high
responsibility of presenting every soul under
his care perfect before God. How is he to
fulfill this requirement? By constant contact
with the individuals that compose the masses. 
Think you? This would be impossible. Is it not rather
through the few whom he has gathered around
him and perfected in the way of the Lord and
by them to reach and perfect others? Let me ask
and answer one other question before & close this
point. What is one of the Efficient Causes of

17
instability in the pastoral relations at the present
time. Is it not because pastors are too content
to stand alone and Enjoy the honor
of doing all the work of the churches themselves and
consequently subject to receive all the blame
if it does not go right? Would it not contribute
largely to the permanency of the pastorate
if each pastor were to rally around him from
the first a few of his best workers and inbed
himself in their hearts by training them and
fitting them to be his co-workers to carry out
his plans and do the work of detail which
so many times not only burden but help
to weaken the pastor? They are his marshals
both for his defence and for attack.
The relations of the pastor to the Sunday School
are very easily determined in the light of a
Normal Class. His duty would not be to 
Superintend the school, nor to teach a class, nor
in any way to interfere with the Management
of the School. There would be no friction between
him and any officer of the school. His work
is done in the Normal Class, Save that of gathering

18
up the fruit of the School or serving in the Capacity of
a pastor. The Superintendent would be left to
carry out the details of the work in his own
way, and to come into direct contact with his teachers in
superintending the special preparation 
of every lesson in the teachers
meeting privilege & a power wh. no Supt. can afford to lose.
In the light of this discussion
it is not then a mere question of privilege
or choice as to whether a pastor has a Normal 
Class but one of duty. We have not stopped
to consider its practicality. It has been
sufficiently tested already to settle that
question beyond a doubt. If a pastor can
sustain a Sunday School he can a Nor. Class.
If he can keep alive a prayer meeting he
can by application and thoroughness keeping alive a Nor. Class. It is a question of no 
ordinary interest or movement. We must keep unclear
with the rapid current of ideas or we shall lose
ground for God. The time to grasp these means
to like these advanced positions is now.

19
III But in the third place we are met with
perhaps the most difficult question of all, and
that is, How can the Nor. Class be successfully
conducted? The question cannot be answered
fully. Every pastor must be his own Engineer.
He cannot work in another man's harness, at
least without gauging it to his own capacities,
and the Circumstances of his Class & Church. Only a
few things in general may be specified. There
is nothing more certain than that any pastor can,
if he will make a Success of this work.
This will not depend upon a 
great number. When Dr. Chalmers gave his lectures
on the "History of Speculative Philosophy of the 19th Century,
he remarked that if he could only interest four
out of 200 Students who heard his lectures he
felt assured that their influence would tell on
all the rest: If you can get but two or three
of your teachers to see the necessity for this kind
of drill, and interested in the Study it will
prove contagious and soon others will be added.
The time for meeting is important. It cannot as
well be sanwitched in or tacked on to some

20
other meeting. It ought to be dignified by having
the best time as it occupies
the first place in all Sabbath School teaching.
Remove it out of its place and you impair its power, if you do not kill it.
It must live for force of its dignity. I know
the great difficulty is a multiplication of appointments.
But the S.S. teacher must be taught
to give more than the dribblings of time to the unclear.
But if for any good reason a separate evening
is overtaxing then let it be joined with
the teachers meeting, but give it an adequate
portion of time, and the best place in the
order of the exercises. Begin and close in
the minute. The place is important,
The ideal would call for a room of its own. Where it
can be sure of undisturbed quiet. And can
center all its interests. The Nor. Class would be permanent institution. A room to be called
the Normal Class Room would ass much to
the permanency of the class, and be the nucleus
of an over increasing power. The library, the
cabinet of specimens, Maps, charts, and all 
necessary equipment would help to gather interest
at that spot.

21
The text book is an all important matter
to be considered. Shall we have one or not?
We answer, by all means, and for the following
among other reasons: In the first place
no pastor can afford the time to prepare
a course of lectures such as the Normal Class
would require. In the Second place, if he
had the time it is not every man who is
able to mark out and elaborate a Course
of this kind. This work belongs to those who
have given these things special attention.
In the third place, the teachers require something
more adapted to their circumstances.
Something that they can carry with them,
to use at odd moments, something as a basis
for their memory, and for constant reference.
And in the fourth place, every argument in
favor of a text book in the public School
applies to the Normal Class. The fundamental
idea of the Class is discipline. True discipline
requires for its basis clear and well ordered
ideas. These the text book is supposed to furnish.
Just such a book as this is the Normal Class

22
Manual Published by our Pub-Soc - and the manual outlines
Pub by the Methodists.
With the time and place designated, and
supplied with a text book we enter
upon the work. The following are some of the things
to be borne in mind in the Management of
the class. It is a voluntary Society, no compulsion
brings them there; all grades are represented,
the old and the young, the educated and the
uneducated, the disciplined and the undisciplined,
those who are quick to apprehend truth and those
who are not, the timid and the bold. Here,
then, is an opportunity to exercise tact, and
use variety, and this must be done.
Some suggestions may here be in order: The 
standard of this class must be something more
than the mere reading over and being able to
comprehend the subject matter of the text books.

as given in the gospels, does not seem
to adequately account for this marvelous
career. We are driving to look
beyond the simple account of His
birth to find the Secret of His unique
life. And even beyond his tragic death to discover the
secret of this present power in the world.
The world presents a series of
inexplicable mysteries, when taken
by itself, connected with history and
human experience, which can be
understood only in the light of the
ruling purpose of His life. 
Which was made manifest in his resurrection.
He alone furnishes the key to the world's 
unsolved problems.

The Revelation of Jesus Christ
Rev. 1:1
The record of Christs introduction unto this
world is comparatively unimportant. It does
not seem to adequately account for
His marvellous career. We are driven
to look beyond the Simple account of
His birth to find the Secret of his
unique life, and Even beyond
His tragic death to discover the reason
for His present power in the world.
This world presents a series of inexplicable
mysteries, when taken by itself,
connected with history and human
experience, which can be understood
only in the light of the ruling purpose
of Xs life. This manifested itself most
clearly at His resurrection.
These three events: His birth,
His death, and His resurrection are the
mountain tops of Chty. These refuse
to be veiled in the Mists of human Scepticism.
His birth was an incarnation, 
His death was a penalty paid, His 
resurrection was a guaranty of power
to complete what He had undertaken.
Jesus X Himself, as the risen Lord
furnishes the key to the worlds
unsolved problems.

2
The Apostle John tell us that the things
made known to him in the Isle of
Patmos was by the revelation of Jesus
Christ. This brings before us a peculiar
phase of Christ's character,
that of revealer, one who entered not as were sent, but as
a necessary and personal factor into the history
of the world, and became Essential to
an intelligent interpretation of
the meaning and value of
life in it. Let us Consider Him
in this character and illustrate this
truth on this beautiful resurrection day morning.
I He is a revealer in the Sense that
He makes clear the meaning of all
history. Take a backward glance.
Aside from Christ, the Old Testament
record would be a series of fabulous
stories. He is essential as the Sun

3
and substance of its history, its
prophecies, its types, and its
ceremonies. Such prophecies as -
"The seed of the woman shall bruise
the serpents head" - "In thy seed shall
all the nations of the Earth be blessed" -
"The desire of all nations shall come",
are meaningless except they are fulfilled
in Christ. The types and Symbols,
as found in the tabernacle, and temple,
in the ark of the Covenant, and other
temple furniture, in the shekinah and
the Sacrificial offerings, Emphatically
demand the Existence of a character
which the world has never found,
Except in the person of Jesus Christ.
Upon the hypothesis that He was what
the Gospel represented Him to be, they
are at once invested with the deepest

4
significance and interest.
The history of nations cannot be
explained without taking Him into
account. Some one has Said that
God is in history, and all history
has a unity because God is in it,
that providence is the light of history,
and the Soul of the world, and that the
work of redemption is the Sum of
all God's providences. From this 
viewpoint the hand of God is distinctly
traced in the history of governments.
Every nation of old was more or
less molded around the purpose
and dealings of God respecting His
ancient people Israel. Every turn
of providence looked toward the Coming
of Christ. Nations rose and fell,
Empire succeeded Empire in the slow

5
and mysterious progress of the nations
toward a universal sovereignty.
Alexander prepared the way for 
intellectual dominion. Caesar for National
dominion. These two Sovereignties
at last stood Side by Side; and
no one could read the secret of such
a culmination of national
forces until Christ revealed its
necessity, in order to the universal
reception of Himself and of His
salvation. Gods peculiar
treatment of the Jewish nation
can be explained only in the light
of the Coming Christ. They were held
in rigorous discipline "until the
fullness of the time" had come. They
were kept as a distinct nationality
amid circumstances under which

6
any other nation would have lost
its identity, only that Christ might
be born of the promised Seed; and
it seems difficult to account
for their present condition as a
people Scattered and peeled except
on the ground of their rejection of
Christ. All ancient history must
be read in the light of this ancient
people, and their history in the light
of Christ. And what is true
of the past is evidently true of
the present, and will be of the future.
The Book of the Revelation is the unfolding
of all history down to the end of time
with Christ as the Central figure.
And I am sure that no one can
so clearly and intelligently interpret
the movements of the nations and 
discern the signs of the times as he

7
who takes his view from the Cross
and the open tomb. Ethics, even, after
reaching the most perfect ideals outside
of Revelation, lacked a Something
which involved a vital defect;
and which, had it been
fully realized, could never have
been Supplied by Sinful humanity;
and that Something was an 
embodiment in a person of the
Entire Ethical System, the perfect
man to live and walk, and suf, and die, and rise again among
men, exhibiting before their gaze
the true ideals of human relations.
That necessity was Supplied in the
fact of Christ revealed. Philosophy
had also made great progress and
had "exhausted itself in the effort to
penetrate between God and the World."

8
and remained in doubt until Christ
solved the problem in His incarnate
life. And so prophecy and history,
symbol and ceremony, the life of
nations and of men, morals and 
philosophy, were all alike involved
in mystery, were aimless and meaningless
without the revelation of Jesus
Christ.
II. As revealer He also opens up a
new and universal end; and the
least Significant among the changes
wrought by His appearing was the
ushering in of a new Era of dates.
The world has set its signature to the
fact of His incarnate existence
by its recognition of the time of His
birth. The Angel's Song of "Peace on

9
Earth, good will to men." furnished
the initial hour which regulates the
worlds calendar. The date of every letter,
the Stamp of every business document,
is a memorial of His life and death, and of his Res.
The material world does not
revolve upon its axis more commercial
world move around the point of
history in which Christ became
incarnate. It was a new
era for humanity. In the very
highest sense Christ was a
revealer of a better way. The light
of the world, The fatherhood of God, and
the brotherhood of man, became lost
truths upon the incoming of Sin into
the human heart. Men without God
in the world, became men without the
sympathies which belong to ta true 
humanity.

10

Pastoral Visitation, with Special reference
to the Model pastoral visit.
There has ever been a uniform opinion
as to the two-fold character of the minister
of the Gospel. He is first of all a preacher,
and Second a pastor. These terms are
so well understood as to require no
Elaborate Explanation. The preacher is
the public man, the orator - the pastor
is the private teacher, counsellor and guide.
The Early Apostolic method is described
in the Acts as follows: "And daily in the
temple and in Every house, they
ceased not to teach and preach
Jesus Christ." And later on Paul
gives his plan of work in his address
to the Elders of Ephesus. "I kept back
nothing that was profitable unto you
but have showed you, and have
taught you publicly, and from
house to house," and adds his Estimate of the practical
success of his method. "Wherefore I
take you to record this day that I am
pure from the blood of all men."

2
This "house to house" work recognises
the value and necessity of personal contact
of individual effort as Supplementary
to the public and more ground work
of the Minister. The Scriptures allude
to the pastor as a Shepherd who has
the care of a flock. The ideal being
given in the prediction of what the
great Shepherd's work would by." He
shall feed his flock like a Shepherd,
he shall gather the lambs with his arm,
and carry them in his bosom, and
shall gently lead those that are with young."
The English term Curate in its technical
sense fittingly describes the pastors work,
meaning one who cares for Souls, or as
Paul Speaks of him, One who "watches
for souls." Too much emphasis 
cannot be laid upon this unclear
of a ministers work in our day.
The reasons being first a Strong
tendency to Exalt the Sermon into undue
prominence as an intellectual production
at the Expense of Everything
Else. The idea of the orator has gained

3

Expounder of Gods Word. So that the
minister is often Satisfied if only
he succeeds in gaining the reputation
of being a fine Speaker and of
drawing the crowds. Where this
impression prevails the distinctive
work of the pastor must inevitably Suffer.
Probably, growing out of the Seemingly
popular demand for intellectual greatness
in the pulpit, is the impression that
pastoral work is at best incidental
and is beneath the dignity of a great
preacher and so should be relegated
to the assistant pastor or to the
church missionary. A Short time
since a western Clergyman wrote to
that prince of preachers and pastors
Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler of Brooklyn N.Y.
inquiring whether Eastern ministers
regard pastoral labor as "befitting an
intellectual and manly ministry."
Surprising as Such a question is

feeling not only among

4

Dr. Cuylers' reply is worthy of repetition.
Said he, What the opinion of other

ministry of Paul and of his
divine Master were both intellectual

labors proves that while they did not

proclamations of truth, they devoted

up a solid compact hand-working,
money-giving church! A Crowd of hearing

5

I There are different senses in which the
term example is used in the Scriptures.
1. For instance there are examples for our
admonition. As Cruden, says they are used
for precedents that we may be admonished
against the sins of others by the judgments
of God on them.
Paul in his letter to the Corinthians Speaks
of the Israelite fathers, that with many of
them God was not well pleased, and they
were over thrown in the wilderness, for they
lusted after Evil things. They were idolators,
fornicators, tempters of Christ, murmurers
and for these reasons were "destroyed of
the destroyer." "Now all these things happened
unto them for Ensamples: and they were 
written for our admonition, upon whom the
Ends of the world are come."
Peter rehearses the destruction of Sodom and

Gomorrha saying that God "condemned
them with an overthrow, making them an
Ensample unto those that after should live
ungodly"
These are examples set in the framework of
judgment, and like pictures are to be 
hung up in the chamber of the memory
reminding us that a similar fate awaits
all who are guilty of similar acts.
2. Then there are Examples for our imitation
These are models for us to copy.

 "When an artist is about to paint a fine
picture, or carve an exquisite statue, he 
secures a pattern as perfect as possible.
If no model exists, he creates one, and from
his own imagination brings out conceptions
of faultless beauty, to guide his pencil or
direct his chisel."
But Christ has not left us to the difficult
task of creating our own models. The Scriptures

II Let us consider then the place and power
of example.
Unquestionably the place of Example is
after precept. We must have ideas before
we can act; We must have truth before
we can walk therein; we must have
precept before we can exemplify.
But the relation which these sustain to Each
other is very Singular and important.
1. Precepts partake of the nature of the abstract.
We often get the thought, but we are at
a loss to know how to transmute it into
an act. We get the theory but find it difficult
to Execute it. Besides it is hard work
often to take in the full meaning of a Statement.
We need to see an illustration.
It may be possible for some men to
understand a theorem from the description

merely, but the most of us require a figure
to be drawn and a demonstration. A blind
man, might form some idea of a rose by
the description that it grows on a certain kind
of a bush has a certain shape and color
and size, and yet what does he know
practically what that bush is or what color
is. He must see it to know. When God
says Thou Shalt love me with all thy heart,
mind, might, and strength and thy neighbor
as thy Self, it is possible for us to
form some idea of what He means, but
it is an idea in the abstract. How
much better we understand it when

The precept of Example is then to follow
The precept, and render it visible, 
and in this its great importance is Sun.

As a live man, in action, has greater
influence over us than his picture

Colleges limped in his walk. After several
